mn147:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn147:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn147:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
mn147:1.3.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

mn147:1.4.eng: “The qualities that ripen in freedom have ripened in Rāhula.
mn147:1.4.comm: Five perceptions that ripen in freedom are taught at DN 33:2.1.139, but apart from that we do not encounter this idea in the discourses. | In SN 18.1–5, Rāhula requests a teaching so he can go on retreat. The teachings given there can be compared with the parallel, which says the Buddha first told Rāhula to teach the five aggregates, the six sense-spheres, and conditionality, and then to go on retreat and meditate on the same teachings (SA 200 at T ii 51a23). Only then did the Buddha consider him ready.

mn147:1.5.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ rāhulaṃ uttariṃ āsavānaṃ khaye vineyyan”ti.
mn147:1.5.eng: Why don’t I lead him further to the ending of defilements?”

mn147:1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn147:1.6.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

mn147:1.7.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ āmantesi:
mn147:1.7.eng: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Rāhula,

mn147:1.8.comm: The sitting cloth was a standard requisite of monastics (Bu Pc 89). Regularly featured in the texts of the Sarvāstivāda schools, it is rarely mentioned in the Pali suttas (but see DN 16:3.1.3).

mn147:1.9.eng: Let’s go to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation.”

mn147:1.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavato paṭissutvā nisīdanaṃ ādāya bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
mn147:1.10.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Rāhula. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.

mn147:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anekāni devatāsahassāni bhagavantaṃ anubandhāni honti:
mn147:2.1.eng: Now at that time many thousands of deities followed the Buddha, thinking,
mn147:2.1.comm: The presence of a thousand deities, which is unique to this discourse, is not mentioned in the Chinese parallel, and is obviously a later addition.

mn147:2.2.pli: “ajja bhagavā āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ uttariṃ āsavānaṃ khaye vinessatī”ti.
mn147:2.2.eng: “Today the Buddha will lead Rāhula further to the ending of defilements!”

mn147:2.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn147:2.3.eng: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Dark Forest and sat at the root of a tree on the seat spread out.

mn147:2.4.pli: Āyasmāpi kho rāhulo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn147:2.4.eng: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

mn147:2.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

mn147:2.7.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:2.9.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:2.9.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:2.11.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:2.11.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:2.12.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:3.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:3.4.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”

mn147:3.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:3.6.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:3.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:3.10.eng: Is eye consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:3.12.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:3.12.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:3.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:3.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:3.15.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:3.18.eng: Is eye contact permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:3.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:3.20.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:3.22.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:3.22.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:3.23.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:3.26.pli: yamidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:3.26.eng: Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:3.28.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:3.28.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:3.30.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:3.30.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:3.31.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:4-8.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi rāhula, sotaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.1.eng: “What do you think, Rāhula? Is the ear …

mn147:4-8.11.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.11.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:4-8.13.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:4-8.13.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:4-8.14.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:4-8.16.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi rāhula, dhammā niccā vā aniccā vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.16.eng: “What do you think, Rāhula? Are ideas permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:4-8.18.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.18.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”

mn147:4-8.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:4-8.20.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:4-8.21.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:4-8.23.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi rāhula, manoviññāṇaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.23.eng: “What do you think, Rāhula? Is mind consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:4-8.25.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.25.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:4-8.27.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:4-8.27.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:4-8.28.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:4-8.30.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi rāhula, manosamphasso nicco vā anicco vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.30.eng: “What do you think, Rāhula? Is mind contact permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:4-8.32.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.32.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:4-8.34.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:4-8.34.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:4-8.35.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:4-8.38.pli: yamidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ, tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.38.eng: Anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

mn147:4-8.40.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn147:4-8.40.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn147:4-8.42.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn147:4-8.42.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn147:4-8.43.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn147:9.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmiṃ nibbindati, rūpesu nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇe nibbindati, cakkhusamphasse nibbindati, yamidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ tasmimpi nibbindati.
mn147:9.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on eye contact.

mn147:9.2.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear …

mn147:9.6.pli: manasmiṃ nibbindati, dhammesu nibbindati, manoviññāṇe nibbindati, manosamphasse nibbindati, yamidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ tasmimpi nibbindati.
mn147:9.6.eng: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises dependent on mind contact.

mn147:9.7.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
mn147:9.7.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn147:9.8.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
mn147:9.8.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

mn147:9.9.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn147:9.10.pli: Attamano āyasmā rāhulo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn147:9.10.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula approved what the Buddha said.

mn147:9.11.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmato rāhulassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
mn147:9.11.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, Rāhula’s mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.

mn147:9.12.pli: Tāsañca anekānaṃ devatāsahassānaṃ virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
mn147:9.12.eng: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in those thousands of deities:

mn147:9.13.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
